revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-09 02:43:45.000000000', 'message': 'Gate fix: Cap hacking to avoid gate failure

hacking is not capped in g-r and it is in
blacklist for requirement as hacking new version
can break the gate jobs.

Hacking can break gate jobs because of various
reasons:
- There might be new rule addition in hacking
- Some rules becomes default from non-default
- Updates in pycodestyle etc

That was the main reason it was not added in g-r
auto sync also. Most of the project maintained the
compatible and cap the hacking version in
test-requirements.txt and update to new version when
project is ready. Bumping new version might need code
fix also on project side depends on what new in that
version.

If project does not have cap the hacking version then,
there is possibility of gate failure whenever new hacking
version is released by QA team.

Example of such failure in recent release of hacking 1.1.0
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130282.html

Change-Id: I688a5f322bba52ae3b9fa5ecab5bed4f58fec542
'}]
commit_message:
Gate fix: Cap hacking to avoid gate failure

hacking is not capped in g-r and it is in
blacklist for requirement as hacking new version
can break the gate jobs.

Hacking can break gate jobs because of various
reasons:
- There might be new rule addition in hacking
- Some rules becomes default from non-default
- Updates in pycodestyle etc

That was the main reason it was not added in g-r
auto sync also. Most of the project maintained the
compatible and cap the hacking version in
test-requirements.txt and update to new version when
project is ready. Bumping new version might need code
fix also on project side depends on what new in that
version.

If project does not have cap the hacking version then,
there is possibility of gate failure whenever new hacking
version is released by QA team.

Example of such failure in recent release of hacking 1.1.0
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130282.html

Change-Id: I688a5f322bba52ae3b9fa5ecab5bed4f58fec542

commit_message:
Remove mox in test_compute_api.py (1)

Replace mox with mock in the following methods in
nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py.

* _test_delete
* _test_delete_resized_part
* _test_delete_shelved_part
* _test_downed_host_part

Subsequent patches will remove mox in other test
methods in the file.

Change-Id: I35821df809d163ba16f1e647ef26b4b97b352bb4
Implements: blueprint mox-removal

Handle port binding activation in the OVS agent

This patch adds code to the OVS agent and the RPC channel to handle the
activation of a port binding by the ML2 plugin

commit_message:
Remove default values of router's is_ha and is_distributed arguments

Those attributes of Neutron's router are by default blocked by
policy.json for regular users. So in such case even if router is ha
or is distributed, regular user would get False values for both
parameters.
This patch changes it by removing default value set to False for those
attributes. Now in such case both those parameters will be set to
None which should be less confusing for users.

Change-Id: I6908000bfc542478775a5f873e4660a9206ce38a
Closes-Bug: #1689510

commit_message:
Update the fast forward workflow to use CLI commands

This change adjusts the fast forward upgrade workflow to use the
Openstack CLI commands instead of running manual ansible commands.

Change-Id: I345500444ed47d631593d96e4a192e179e4bb326
(cherry picked from commit 26a7d9055505ce1c05fbcc808bbbf09ec7aefd08)

commit_message:
Allow creating subnet without a gateway

The ability to create a subnet without a gateway was broken
in commit 0ddc93b1b19922d08bedf331b57c363535bb357e.  Change
the create_subnet() method back to using '' as the default
value for the gateway so that callers can pass-in None as
before.  This allows the trunk test to revert to its previous
behavior of passing None.

Change-Id: Ib010f277f4c9ad8a708d16debdcdf8d2ceccd051
Closes-Bug: #1769609

commit_message:
tasks: Ensure /etc/keystone/credential-keys is created on time

We need to ensure that {{ keystone_credential_key_repository }} is
created along with the rest of directories in order to prevent problems
like the following one:

OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/etc/keystone/credential-keys'

Depends-On: I5a78e2120e596d36629b4ba978b2b5df76b149b0
Change-Id: I394e069f9cbea7b85e5f6f53e3d3f9f54494dafe

commit_message:
log stale allocations as WARNING instead of DEBUG

Stale resource allocations can prevent Nova from scheduling new
instances on a host that otherwise has sufficient resources available.
Nova would log a message about this situation on the affected compute
node, but it was logged at DEBUG priority and so would typically not
be visible in a production environment.

This commit modifies Nova to log the message as a warning instead.

Change-Id: I347d2ab0077c4d9b62bc169af9e039d00ec214fa
Closes-bug: #1767553
(cherry picked from commit a54e5ed00f98b8536080647e5caa90d556d6e809)
(cherry picked from commit 12a3b698d17672ec0277dff4e96c44a92186aab1)

commit_message:
Migrate tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration job in-tree

This defines the nova-live-migration job, based on the
tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration job from openstack-zuul-jobs.

The branch override parts of the job definition are removed since
the job will be defined per-branch now.

Conflicts:
      .zuul.yaml

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having job
nova-tox-functional-py35 in stable/ocata.

Change-Id: Idea86d6bb648b1e6fef8813dbe569724ce81a750
(cherry picked from commit 7d8246244db56420e8c3512f991604ffda9bcc12)
(cherry picked from commit 0db59f717275a004c2f6c12f1248110dbb425587)
(cherry picked from commit a4adf3b7a36c01cf741313290b8994c34cc866bb)

commit_message:
Remove legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration job usage

The live migration job definition is being moved to nova and renamed to
'nova-live-migration'. The job usage is now defined in nova
and tempest repos so we can remove the legacy job name usage from
project-config.

Note that the related per-repo patches will need to be backported to
stable branches to run the job there.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555945
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/565608

Change-Id: I8f7b62d96320ce71a4bfa25c2d9a36e973bf6eb6

commit_message:
Remove service-type override tests

The upcoming changes to openstascksdk for supporting discovery properly
make these irrelevant ... and actually incorrect. Remove them so we can
land the discovery support. Also, update test_getters to account for
the volume to block-storage shift.

Change-Id: I485fe36e0f3a1ae97e8254a784c37b7fa641844d

would this need to be backported to stable branches?

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#for-new-requirements'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-08 16:12:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-08 16:46:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-08 16:47:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

probably this needs backport. but right now i'm concentrating on master.

i updated the commit message."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-08 19:01:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-05-08 19:15:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Since this is not an official project, releases for these are done by the individual project.

It could be proposed to come under governance and start using the release management team for processing releases, but that would be up to the team if they want to do and I don't believe is necessary for adding to requirements."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-08 19:21:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This looks OK except that it adds the project to the blacklist which means any two projects that want to depend on this won't be ensured to have compatible versions in their requirements files. Is that what we want? I see that we do the same for other networking projects, and I'm not sure why we do that."}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 03:39:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

wrt the governance, tap-as-a-service project aimed to be a neutron subproject eventually. but the effort has been slow.

wrt blacklist, i actually don't know why. i just followed what has been done for similar networking projects."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-09 04:09:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

is tap-as-a-service midonet specific? if so adding it to blacklist is likely fine (plugins don't need to be co-installablie imo)  if it is a more generic lib, not adding it to blacklist.txt makes more sense"}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 04:24:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Matthew,

tap-as-a-service is not midonet specific.
it works in the same way as other neutron-xxx, which are all in the blacklist for some reasons.'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 04:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Andreas,

can you explain why you put these networking projects in blacklist?
is it still necessary?'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-09 04:59:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

if it's not midonet specific then it should not be in the blacklist imo"}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 05:34:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Matthew,

do you mean the most of these networking projects should be removed from the blacklist?'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-09 05:47:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

no, just their dependencies if their dependencies are only to be used for those networking plugins'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-09 05:47:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm still under the impression that the plugins are not guaranteed to be co-installable."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-05-09 05:59:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I put those into blacklist since projects failed that still used tox_install.sh otherwise. See https://review.openstack.org/552865'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-05-09 05:59:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So, blacklist should not be needed if the repos that use tap-as-a-service don't have tox_install"}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 09:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Matthew,

i'm not sure if i understand your concerns.
what do you mean by "those networking plugins"?
neutron can load multiple plugins as far as they are of different kinds. (CORE, L3, ...)
how is it related to this blacklist?'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 09:30:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Andreas,

as far as i know, networking-midonet is the only project which uses tox_install for tap-as-a-service.'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 09:34:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 11:03:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

does it need to be added upper-constraints instead?

2018-05-09 09:37:19.728830 | ubuntu-xenial | Checking /home/zuul/src/git.openstack.org/openstack/requirements/blacklist.txt
2018-05-09 09:37:19.728905 | ubuntu-xenial | 'tap-as-a-service' appears in global-requirements.txt but not upper-constraints.txt or blacklist.txt"}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-09 12:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-09 14:06:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Should you be able to install all plugins at the same time?  If so, the plugins should not be listed in blacklist.txt.  If not they should stay.
If you CAN use tap-as-a-service outside of the plugin (which you indicated is true), you should not list it in blacklist.txt so we can ensure it is co-installable with the rest of openstack (we don't care that it's used in a plugin for the test)."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-09 14:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

oh, you removed it'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-09 14:59:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

needs a lower-constraint as well (in lower-constraints.txt)'}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-05-10 04:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-10 14:48:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-05-10 19:34:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-10 20:13:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

Change-Id: Ifed26d4cd9477b7d421718a95d475d85a9720e1f
"}, {'created': '2018-05-08 16:46:02.000000000', 'message': "Add tap-as-a-service

Now it's published on PyPI.
Add it to global-requirements, following the similar change. [1]

This is necessary for networking-midonet.  See [2].
Note: this is not a library. It provides a Neutron service plugin
as some of Neutron subprojects like neutron-vpnaas do.
networking-midonet has a driver for this service plugin and
associated unit tests, which currently requires this.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552865/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555788/

The following answers the questions on:
https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#for-new-requirements

> Is the library actively maintained?

It's maintained.  Not very active these days though.

> Is the library good code?

It's following Neutron standard. (loosely)

> Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

> Is the library license compatible?

Yes. Same license as Neutron.

> Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest / Fedora latest)?

https://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=python-neutron-taas

I have no idea about Fedora.

> Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in global-requirements.txt?

No.

> Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes. networking-midonet has a driver for this project.

> If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

No. It isn't a library.
Ideally it should be cycle-with-milestones.

> Do I need to update anything else?

I'm not sure what this question means.

Change-Id: Ifed26d4cd9477b7d421718a95d475d85a9720e1f

commit_message:
Add tap-as-a-service

Now it's published on PyPI.
Add it to global-requirements, following the similar change. [1]

This is necessary for networking-midonet.  See [2].
Note: this is not a library. It provides a Neutron service plugin
as some of Neutron subprojects like neutron-vpnaas do.
networking-midonet has a driver for this service plugin and
associated unit tests, which currently requires this.

This commit doesn't add it to blacklist.txt because:
	- as far as I know, networking-midonet is the only project which
	  uses tox_install to install tap-as-a-service
	- and its gate is currently broken and we plan to retire
	  tox_install to fix it. [2]

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552865/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555788/

The following answers the questions on:
https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#for-new-requirements

> Is the library actively maintained?

It's maintained.  Not very active these days though.

> Is the library good code?

It's following Neutron standard. (loosely)

> Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

> Is the library license compatible?

Yes. Same license as Neutron.

> Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest / Fedora latest)?

https://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=python-neutron-taas

I have no idea about Fedora.

> Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in global-requirements.txt?

No.

> Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes. networking-midonet has a driver for this project.

> If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process does it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

No. It isn't a library.
Ideally it should be cycle-with-milestones.

> Do I need to update anything else?

I'm not sure what this question means.

Change-Id: Ifed26d4cd9477b7d421718a95d475d85a9720e1f

messages: [{'account_id': 2463, 'date': '2018-05-08 15:23:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-05-08 16:47:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-05-10 20:00:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-08 15:23:08.000000000', 'message': 'Only allow SG port ranges for whitelisted protocols

Iptables only supports port-ranges for certain protocols,
others will generate failures, possibly leaving the agent
looping trying to apply rules.  Change to not allow port
ranges outside of the list of known good protocols.

Change-Id: I5867f77fc5aedc169b42f50def0424ff209c164c
Closes-bug: #1749667
(cherry picked from commit b564871bb759a38cf96527f94e7c7d4cc760b1c9)
'}]
commit_message:
Only allow SG port ranges for whitelisted protocols

Iptables only supports port-ranges for certain protocols,
others will generate failures, possibly leaving the agent
looping trying to apply rules.  Change to not allow port
ranges outside of the list of known good protocols.

Change-Id: I5867f77fc5aedc169b42f50def0424ff209c164c
Closes-bug: #1749667
(cherry picked from commit b564871bb759a38cf96527f94e7c7d4cc760b1c9)

commit_message:
[L3][QoS] Cover mixed dvr_snat and compute node dvr router

The dvr_snat node can also run the nova-compute which will
make the fip_qos l3 agent extension failed to install the
qos tc rules for the dvr router floating IPs.

To cover such mixed deployment, the tc rules for floating IP
qos will be processed again in qrouter-namespace of the
dvr_snat node, and the device is rfp-device.

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/extensions/test_fip_qos_extension.py

Change-Id: I9eca25201e0647d4da77b325fba03cca1db5bb4d
Closes-Bug: #1758316
(cherry picked from commit 35365ead42eec24027140d3cfd9dfeb40316e8d6)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-09 08:11:44.000000000', 'message': "Monitor phys_bridges to reconfigured it if created again

In case when external bridge configured in OVS agent's bridge_mappings
will be destroyed and created again (for example by running ifup-ovs
script on Centos) bridge wasn't configured by OVS agent.
That might cause broken connectivity for OpenStack's dataplane if
dataplane network also uses same bridge.

This patch adds additional ovsdb-monitor to monitor if any
of physical bridges configured in bridge_mappings was created.
If so, agent will reconfigure it to restore proper openflow rules
on it.

Change-Id: I9c0dc587e70327e03be5a64522d0c679665f79bd
Closes-Bug: #1768990
(cherry picked from commit 85b46cd51ebec67d5018d8bef4f796ee5ef4fedf)
"}]
commit_message:
Monitor phys_bridges to reconfigured it if created again

In case when external bridge configured in OVS agent's bridge_mappings
will be destroyed and created again (for example by running ifup-ovs
script on Centos) bridge wasn't configured by OVS agent.
That might cause broken connectivity for OpenStack's dataplane if
dataplane network also uses same bridge.

This patch adds additional ovsdb-monitor to monitor if any
of physical bridges configured in bridge_mappings was created.
If so, agent will reconfigure it to restore proper openflow rules
on it.

Change-Id: I9c0dc587e70327e03be5a64522d0c679665f79bd
Closes-Bug: #1768990
(cherry picked from commit 85b46cd51ebec67d5018d8bef4f796ee5ef4fedf)

commit_message:
Add support for using distribution packages for OpenStack services

Distributions provide packages for the OpenStack services so we add
support for using these instead of the pip ones.

Change-Id: I4ff3cbf5e1e1ce04cd4cdc9c1ce97afdeace5159
Depends-On: I5a78e2120e596d36629b4ba978b2b5df76b149b0
Implements: blueprint openstack-distribution-packages

commit_message:
Move the keys methods of volume type to manager

We can move these methods to manager, and provide
the unify interfaces as other mentods.

Change-Id: I1559fa215d08a5b705b60a073df510b2785de7c7

We could refactor _is_crypt_device_available or just introduce another method in the CryptsetupEncryptor class to check if the device already exists. revisions:
[{'created': '2017-05-05 01:28:53.000000000', 'message': "check volume status before open/close volume

To encrypt a volume with luks, we need follow two steps:[1]
1. create the luks encryptor with volume connectioninfo. {'data':'device_path'}
   connectioninfo['data']['device_path'] is the symlink to the real device.
2. call encryptor.attach_volume to encrypt the volume.
   attach_volume finds the real device from the symlink, then create a encrypted partition from the real device.
   At last, points the symlink to the encrypted partition instead of the device.

Thinking that we call attach_volume again.
1. create luks encryptor with connectioninfo.
2. Now attach_volume wants to find the real device from the symlink. But it will get the partition instead of the device.
   Because it had points the symlink to the encrypted partition in last attach_volume.

This patch is to check if volume is already opened before attach_volume opens the volume.
Also do the check before closing volume.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/16.0.0.0b1/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L1241-L1244

Change-Id: I10fae64613cd1f6562e43b495c956894be134632

commit_message:
Check volume status before open/close volume

To encrypt a volume with luks, we need following two steps:[1]
1. create the luks encryptor with volume connection_info.
   connection_info['data']['device_path'] is the symlink to
   the real device.
2. call encryptor.attach_volume to open the volume.
   attach_volume finds the real device from the symlink,
   then create a encrypted partition from the real device.
   At last, it points the symlink to the encrypted partition
   instead of the device.

Thinking that we call attach_volume again.
1. create luks encryptor with connectioninfo.
2. Now attach_volume wants to find the real device from the symlink.
   But it will get the partition instead of the device.
   Because it had pointed the symlink to the encrypted partition
   in last attach_volume.

This patch is to check if volume is already opened before attach_volume
opens the volume. Also do the check before closing volume.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/37438e21efbf3877e5f84dd791a
    0497af7af66cf/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L1232-L1235

Change-Id: I10fae64613cd1f6562e43b495c956894be134632

commit_message:
Unreadable output of upload-to-image.

The output of upload-to-image is not readable due to
volume type is printed in output as a whole.
Printing volume type id only cleans up the output.

Change-Id: I36b3c830468f820058da56ef6c0f78d3b08ba172
Closes-Bug: #1557486

The device path to a block device on Ubuntu using a ds8k LUN
differs from the device path for other storage systems.

This patch adds the new device path as third possibility.

Change-Id: I92f1e5a2c7203af6c01c4742067ced16a840eb04
(cherry picked from commit f28bd8ea85264a668abfb30bec1e812bda2b75a5)
'}]
commit_message:
s390x fc: Fix device path for Ubuntu with ds8k

The device path to a block device on Ubuntu using a ds8k LUN
differs from the device path for other storage systems.

This patch adds the new device path as third possibility.

Change-Id: I92f1e5a2c7203af6c01c4742067ced16a840eb04
(cherry picked from commit f28bd8ea85264a668abfb30bec1e812bda2b75a5)

> aren't we sending the connector back to cinder to store in the attachments table now? If nova pulls the v.o. for this, won't it also have to ask for the dict, so Cinder will be happy?

We'd have to store a version of it somewhere, with the version each side knows about, so we can do conversions (obj_to_primitive) between services. The same thing has been discussed for a long time between nova and neutron with "vif negotiation" and the os-vif library, but it hasn't been implemented over the REST APIs between nova and neutron yet, which is why I said at the PTG that we likely should hold off on doing this in os-brick until we actually see how the pattern works for vif negotiation first, but then Lee kicked me in the head and made me restore this.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-05-10 20:59:27.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

commit_message:
Model initiator connector properties as versioned object

Long-term nova would like to start modeling the volume connector
dict as a versioned object, and the libvirt driver in nova is getting
it's connector properties from os-brick.

So it follows that os-brick would start modeling it's connector
properties with a versioned object and then nova could start consuming
that.

Change-Id: I259f8c36cfafcde0138c4457730f17e4470c1ccf

commit_message:
Return all resources only when required

Our list CLI will return all resources in default,
this could consume lots of resource if adminstrator
has thousands of volumes. This patch changes the
behavior that only return the whole list if the
administrator requires to.

Now the upgraded behaviors are below:

1. cinder list # Only return the volume list smaller
or equal to the osapi_max_limit.
2. cinder list --limit -1 # Return the full volume list.
3. cinder list --limit <any value except -1>
   # Return the desired volume list.

Change-Id: Iead230b8874193784eb52b447af546b73b8b158d
Closes-Bug: #1726770

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 10:42:28.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Fix LUKS error logs in n-cpu

This patch fixes error logs 'is not valid LUKS device'
in n-cpu. The logs were generated while trying to open
a non-formatted LUKS volume, This patch adds a check
to verify LUKS volume before opening it.

commit_message:
[WIP] Fix LUKS error logs in n-cpu

This patch fixes error logs 'is not valid LUKS device'
in n-cpu. The logs were generated while trying to open
a non-formatted LUKS volume, This patch adds a check
to verify LUKS volume before opening it.

Change-Id: I7b5aabdfe6c487af380f20ae33ca9e15bfdeb13d
Closes-Bug: 1735780

[{'account_id': 27849, 'date': '2018-02-20 15:32:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-02-20 15:32:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 27710, 'date': '2018-02-20 15:49:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase OSBrick Windows CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase OSBrick Windows CI

- os-brick-iscsi http://cloudbase-ci.com/os-brick/546185/1/iscsi/ : FAILURE in 17m 19s
- os-brick-smb http://cloudbase-ci.com/os-brick/546185/1/smb/ : FAILURE in 17m 18s'}, {'account_id': 24502, 'date': '2018-02-20 16:55:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build failed. For 3rd party CI contact info: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems

- dsvm-veritas-hyperscale-os-brick http://52.35.51.88/85/546185/1/check/dsvm-veritas-hyperscale-os-brick/814ba5c : FAILURE in 1h 22m 24s'}, {'account_id': 21976, 'date': '2018-02-20 17:12:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- kaminario-dsvm-tempest-full-iscsi http://54.209.116.144/85/546185/1/check/kaminario-dsvm-tempest-full-iscsi/ee43a50 : SUCCESS in 1h 34m 02s
- kaminario-dsvm-tempest-full-FC http://54.209.116.144/85/546185/1/check/kaminario-dsvm-tempest-full-FC/03a1c57 : SUCCESS in 1h 32m 54s'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2018-02-21 10:10:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

This is unnecessary, any valid IQN will not need changes as it will, as far as I now, always comply with udev rules.

Even if we don't have it explicitly mentioned in the definition of the IQN type [1], I believe it is implicit that the type follows the conventions of the domain names [2] with the exception of the optional colons.

Am I missing something?

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3720#section-3.2.6.3.1
[2] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#section-2.3"}, {'account_id': 27849, 'date': '2018-02-24 14:23:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > This is unnecessary, any valid IQN will not need changes as it
 > will, as far as I now, always comply with udev rules.
 > 
 > Even if we don't have it explicitly mentioned in the definition of
 > the IQN type [1], I believe it is implicit that the type follows
 > the conventions of the domain names [2] with the exception of the
 > optional colons.
 > 
 > Am I missing something?
 > 
 > [1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3720#section-3.2.6.3.1
 > [2] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1035#section-2.3

The main point of this patch is that RFC 3720 does not seem to impose any restrictions for the optional part of the iSCSI name. Quoting from [1]:

  The iSCSI qualified name string consists of:

  ...

  - An optional, colon (:) prefixed, string within the character
    set and length boundaries that the owner of the domain name
    deems appropriate.
    ...
    With the exception of the colon prefix, the owner of the 
    domain name can assign everything after the reversed domain
    name as desired.

This means that pretty much any vendor specific IQN (that might also include commas) is valid. Still, udev, seems to allow only a specific set of characters, and replaces any character outside this set with "_" (see GH links mentioned in the commit message of the submitted patch).

In this case, os-brick needs to determine the actual name chosen by udev for the device node. This patch extends ISCSIConnector() to account for this behavior.

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3720#section-3.2.6.3.1'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2018-04-03 10:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Pretty sure that when the specs says "everything after" what they mean is that you don't have to follow a specific pattern like the iqn fixed part, the date, or the reverse domain organization, and not that you can use any character you want.

And afaik the comma is used as a delimiter for the values, and the only allowed characters after the optional colon are those of the "text-value":

     text-value: A string of zero or more characters that consist of
       letters, digits, dot, minus, plus, commercial at, underscore,
       slash, left bracket, right bracket, or colon.

And apparently I'm not the only one that interpreted this in this manner, as I have checked at least 3 different backends and they all reject things like a comma.  Have you found an storage array that supports commas in the IQNs and where you can connect then using those IQNs?'}, {'account_id': 27849, 'date': '2018-04-05 10:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Pretty sure that when the specs says "everything after" what they
 > mean is that you don't have to follow a specific pattern like the
 > iqn fixed part, the date, or the reverse domain organization, and
 > not that you can use any character you want.
 > 
 > And afaik the comma is used as a delimiter for the values, and the
 > only allowed characters after the optional colon are those of the
 > "text-value":
 > 
 > text-value: A string of zero or more characters that consist of
 > letters, digits, dot, minus, plus, commercial at, underscore,
 > slash, left bracket, right bracket, or colon.
 > 
 > And apparently I'm not the only one that interpreted this in this
 > manner, as I have checked at least 3 different backends and they
 > all reject things like a comma.  Have you found an storage array
 > that supports commas in the IQNs and where you can connect then
 > using those IQNs?

I understand your argument about how the spec refers to freedom on the *pattern* and not freedom about choosing arbitrary characters. I started with udev limitations in mind, and attempted to make a generic patch, but I do understand that commas in the IQN were a bad example to make my case. Still, based on your sayings above, if I understand correctly, the allowed '/[]' will be replaced by udev with '_'. But since these chars are not commonly used, feel free to drop this patch. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2018-04-06 08:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, apparently I was also wrong and the allowed characters for the optional part after the colon are not those of "text-value", because / [] aren't allowed either by the backends I checked.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-05-10 20:58:39.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment and currently blocked by a core reviewer with a -2. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and contacting the reviewer with the -2 on this review to ensure you address their concerns.'}]

Along with the iSCSI portal, munge the IQN as well, to comply with
udev rules imposed by systemd [1]. In a nutshell, replace all
characters other than #+-.:=@_ plus the alphanumeric ones with
underscore [2].

[1] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/91761b1846a210323a83e2030ad88a9be5294ce2/src/libudev/libudev-util.c#L231
[2] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/91761b1846a210323a83e2030ad88a9be5294ce2/src/basic/device-nodes.c#L28

'}]
commit_message:
iscsi: Take into account udev rules for devnodes

Along with the iSCSI portal, munge the IQN as well, to comply with
udev rules imposed by systemd [1]. In a nutshell, replace all
characters other than #+-.:=@_ plus the alphanumeric ones with
underscore [2].

[1] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/91761b1846a210323a83e2030ad88a9be5294ce2/src/libudev/libudev-util.c#L231
[2] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/91761b1846a210323a83e2030ad88a9be5294ce2/src/basic/device-nodes.c#L28

Change-Id: Ic09bdb3f3980224cc238dfbabfd503c589a1f4b8
Signed-off-by: Dimitris Aragiorgis <dimara@arrikto.com>

Apologies Walter, while updating Tempest to use the new constants in Id221414d74af8413084c7935b762f93b7ce43c42 it was highlighted that we can't drop the legacy names until Newton is EOL during Queens and I forgot to revisit this review.

commit_message:
encryptors: Block the use of encryptor class paths or names

New provider constants were introduced during Ocata by
Ic155bd29d46059832cce970bf60375e7e472eca6 that in turn deprecated the
use of encryptor class paths or names to identity each encryptor.

The removal of the support for the use of these paths and names was
delayed in Pike by Ib8ca7ecb5494cd4fcae0657525d4c17bfc4ae37e after it
was noted that support would need to remain until Newton hit EOL.

As this is now the case we can finally remove support in Rocky once
Id221414d74af8413084c7935b762f93b7ce43c42 has removed the remaining
references from Tempest.

Depends-On: Id221414d74af8413084c7935b762f93b7ce43c42
Change-Id: I3eec91e221692177833909e0378116cea4966807

commit_message:
Fix log rotation in monasca agent

Observed AttributeError in forwarder and collector logs due to
missing import of logging module handlers.

Added missing import and removed module level import.

Task:15058
Story: 2001941
Change-Id: I62b03bb550c8b01ce9ea5bb4ba49a2ac00763d68

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-19 14:17:31.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid mixing pip and distribution packages

The virtualenv and keystoneclient packages are being installed by PIP
but that means that a whole bunch of required dependencies are being
pulled in as well. This brings the host to a rather messed up state
since distribution and PIP packages are being mixed together. We can
simply avoid that by pulling the required packages from the distribution
repositories.

Depends-On: Ib64dcbc960df7d369d202ce8cf7bdc29b3ee0e0a
Change-Id: Ia51a1f4081b3a56819237d0352cc27c1f32f433c
Implements: blueprint openstack-distribution-packages
'}, {'created': '2018-04-19 16:30:04.000000000', 'message': "Avoid mixing pip and distribution packages

The virtualenv and keystoneclient packages are being installed by PIP
but that means that a whole bunch of required dependencies are being
pulled in as well. This brings the host to a rather messed up state
since distribution and PIP packages are being mixed together. We can
simply avoid that by pulling the required packages from the distribution
repositories. However, the distro virtualenv may put an old PIP in the
virtual environment, so we need to make sure that PIP is the first
package that's being updated so we can use the --constrains parameter.

Depends-On: Ib64dcbc960df7d369d202ce8cf7bdc29b3ee0e0a
Change-Id: Ia51a1f4081b3a56819237d0352cc27c1f32f433c
Implements: blueprint openstack-distribution-packages

repositories. However, the distro virtualenv may put an old PIP in the
virtual environment, so we need to make sure that PIP is the first

environment, so we still need to use the virtualenv package from PIP
for the time being.

Depends-On: I5a78e2120e596d36629b4ba978b2b5df76b149b0
Depends-On: Ib64dcbc960df7d369d202ce8cf7bdc29b3ee0e0a
Change-Id: Ia51a1f4081b3a56819237d0352cc27c1f32f433c
Implements: blueprint openstack-distribution-packages

commit_message:
Do not pip install keystoneclient on the host

The keystoneclient package is being installed on the host by PIP but
that means that a whole bunch of required dependencies are being pulled
in as well.

This brings the host to a rather messed up state when installing
keystone from distro packages, since distribution and
PIP packages are being mixed together. We can simply avoid that by
only using the virtualenv where required, in which the keystone client
would be installed. We still require the virtualenv package to be
installed on the host from PIP at the moment to get the expected
recent version of pip inside the virtualenv.

Depends-On: I5a78e2120e596d36629b4ba978b2b5df76b149b0
Depends-On: Ib64dcbc960df7d369d202ce8cf7bdc29b3ee0e0a
Change-Id: Ia51a1f4081b3a56819237d0352cc27c1f32f433c
Implements: blueprint openstack-distribution-packages

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-07 15:31:23.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Add Serial-over-LAN (SOL) support"

This reverts commit 9f7bfb9f6bc3d561c9a669e9bed3364d610a9642.

It seems that the SOL feature introduced by patch [1] led to the VirtualBMC daemons leaking two file descriptors (ends of UNIX pipe, perhaps) per each IPMI query it processes. Given the default ulimit of 1024 open files per process, in cca 500 IPMI queries vbmc renders itself not quite functional.

The quick research of the problem reveals that the leak comes to life once the virEventRegisterDefaultImpl() call is made which prepares libvirt for asynchronous operations over a dedicated connection to libvirtd. Even though once SOL session is gone and libvirt is cleaned up (well, dedicated connection is closed), the libvirt connection, which is open every time when IPMI query comes in, leaks 2 FDs per query.

This problem has been reported about some other libvirt application in the past [2] so the problem might go away if we turn the IPMI part of vbmc to the asynchronous operation mode as well.

Another observation is that libvirt API may not [3] offer a full clean up upon exiting from the asynchronous operation mode.

To summarize: the real cause of this behaviour is not yet properly understood.

1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/482853/
2. https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2013-September/msg00019.html
3. https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/master/src/util/virevent.c#L224


Change-Id: Id599f62e0eaf8c96e4552d2cd263f93155f8afa6
Story: 2001976
Task: 19585

commit_message:
Revert "Add Serial-over-LAN (SOL) support"

This reverts commit 9f7bfb9f6bc3d561c9a669e9bed3364d610a9642.

It seems that the SOL feature introduced by patch [1] led to
the VirtualBMC daemons leaking two file descriptors (ends of
UNIX pipe, perhaps) per each IPMI query it processes. Given the
default ulimit of 1024 open files per process, in circa 500 IPMI
queries vbmc renders itself not quite functional.

The quick research of the problem reveals that the leak comes
to life once the virEventRegisterDefaultImpl() call is made
which prepares libvirt for asynchronous operations over a dedicated
connection to libvirtd. Even though once SOL session is gone and
libvirt is cleaned up (well, dedicated connection is closed),
the libvirt connection, which is open every time when IPMI query
comes in, leaks 2 FDs per query.

This problem has been reported about some other libvirt application
in the past [2] so the problem might go away if we turn the IPMI
part of vbmc to the asynchronous operation mode as well.

Another observation is that libvirt API may not [3] offer a full
clean up upon exiting from the asynchronous operation mode.

To summarize: the real cause of this behaviour is not yet properly
understood.

1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/482853/
2. https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2013-September/msg00019.html
3. https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/master/src/util/virevent.c#L224

Change-Id: Id599f62e0eaf8c96e4552d2cd263f93155f8afa6
Story: 2001976
Task: 19585

commit_message:
Remove distro package indexing from py_pkgs lookup

The indexing of distro packages by the py_pkgs lookup was
intended for a purpose which never came to fruition. As
such it is not used. The resulting output is somewhat
confusing and very verbose. As such, I think it's best
to remove it.

Change-Id: I0d133804a91feae03e44047eede589c75806b2da

Change-Id: Ia30cee0e0e482477c50ce02c244d0cc19b3c6956

commit_message:
Fix permissions for lsync

Since the lsync process is using the nginx user for repo server
synchronization the /var/www/repo/pools directory needs to be accessible
to the nginx user not the root user.

Change-Id: Ia30cee0e0e482477c50ce02c244d0cc19b3c6956
(cherry picked from commit 14254375b1cb2623be0cce7a21ea5925cd19f0c5)

[{'created': '2018-05-01 22:58:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add nova-live-migration to experimental queue jobs

The legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration job is being moved
into the nova repo and renamed to nova-live-migration. This change adds
the new job name to the in-tree definition of the experimental queue
jobs that run on tempest changes. A project-config change will depend
on this patch to undefine the legacy job name from being used on
tempest changes.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555945

Change-Id: If8150527a358cfe634a604259af47419369fbdc3
'}]
commit_message:
Add nova-live-migration to experimental queue jobs

The legacy-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration job is being moved
into the nova repo and renamed to nova-live-migration. This change adds
the new job name to the in-tree definition of the experimental queue
jobs that run on tempest changes. A project-config change will depend
on this patch to undefine the legacy job name from being used on
tempest changes.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555945

Change-Id: If8150527a358cfe634a604259af47419369fbdc3

The repo build does not need to build the requirements necessary
for role tests. This wastes time unnecessarily and increases the
size of the lookup output, making it more confusing than it
already is.

The REQUIREMENTS_FILE_TYPES it looks for is now reduced to only
'requirements.txt' and 'global-requirement-pins.txt'.

(cherry picked from commit 3a8f658e96ab4e4a7e21cf3a71dd850cbdefa90d)

commit_message:
Remove test-requirements files from py_pkgs lookup

The repo build does not need to build the requirements necessary
for role tests. This wastes time unnecessarily and increases the
size of the lookup output, making it more confusing than it
already is.

The REQUIREMENTS_FILE_TYPES it looks for is now reduced to only
'requirements.txt' and 'global-requirement-pins.txt'.

Change-Id: I11acc957ce4fe6024a40d5bb048a448deaf41778

commit_message:
Remove test-requirements files from py_pkgs lookup

The repo build does not need to build the requirements necessary
for role tests. This wastes time unnecessarily and increases the
size of the lookup output, making it more confusing than it
already is.

The REQUIREMENTS_FILE_TYPES it looks for is now reduced to only
'requirements.txt' and 'global-requirement-pins.txt'.

Change-Id: I11acc957ce4fe6024a40d5bb048a448deaf41778
(cherry picked from commit 3a8f658e96ab4e4a7e21cf3a71dd850cbdefa90d)

a repo build. The packages aren't required for a successful
deployment of OpenStack. The output of their data just adds
noise to the output of the lookup, and delays the build with
unnecessary extra wheel builds.

subject: [ThreadGroup] Don't remove timer when stop timers
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2813, 'name': 'Mehdi Abaakouk', 'email': 'sileht@sileht.net', 'username': 'sileht'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 6722, 'name': 'ChangBo Guo(gcb)', 'email': 'guochbo@cn.ibm.com', 'username': 'guochbo'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 7385, 'name': 'Thomas Herve', 'email': 'therve@redhat.com', 'username': 'therve'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23083, 'name': 'TommyLike', 'email': 'tommylikehu@gmail.com', 'username': 'TommyLike'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-04-03 07:42:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2018-04-03 08:54:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The commit message does not explain what you are trying to fix. Maybe a link to a bug report ?

Also I'm guessing the tests change pass without the code change."}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-04-03 12:00:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-04-04 06:24:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-04-11 03:52:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-05-04 15:19:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

This looks like it would fix the bug, but unfortunately stop_timers is a public function and this is a potentially significant change in behavior.  Most of the callers to stop_timers appear to be at shutdown time, so it shouldn't be a concern that the timers are no longer being cleaned up.  However, I see Heat is calling it on stack delete, and I'm a little concerned that it might cause a memory leak.

I've added some Heat devs to the review to see if they can comment on whether this would be a problem for them.

If it is a problem, I would suggest splitting the wait function into wait_timers and wait_threads, then making wait itself just call both of those.  Then in stop we could call wait_timers before deleting the timers in stop_timers (this would require propagating the graceful param to stop_timers, but that should be fine).

The more I think about it, the more I think that might be the correct thing to do here anyway.  The underlying issue is that we split the timer and thread stopping, but the wait function tries to handle both in one call.  If there were also two wait functions then they could be called at the appropriate time."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-07 23:54:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

It'd be nice if there was a bug report so we didn't all have to independently work out what this is trying to fix.

> I would suggest splitting the wait function into wait_timers and wait_threads, then making wait itself just call both of those. Then in stop we could call wait_timers before deleting the timers in stop_timers

Agree with Ben.

> (this would require propagating the graceful param to stop_timers, but that should be fine)

Alternatively, you could return the list of timers that were stopped from stop_timers(), and pass that as a parameter to the new _wait_timers() method."}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-05-08 00:53:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> It'd be nice if there was a bug report so we didn't all have to
 > independently work out what this is trying to fix.
 > 
 > > I would suggest splitting the wait function into wait_timers and
 > wait_threads, then making wait itself just call both of those. Then
 > in stop we could call wait_timers before deleting the timers in
 > stop_timers
 > 
 > Agree with Ben.
 > 
 > > (this would require propagating the graceful param to
 > stop_timers, but that should be fine)
 > 
 > Alternatively, you could return the list of timers that were
 > stopped from stop_timers(), and pass that as a parameter to the new
 > _wait_timers() method.

thanks, will fix these as suggested soon:)"}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-05-08 06:52:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-08 13:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2018-05-09 00:55:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-09 19:25:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-05-10 15:14:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Looks good, thanks!'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-05-10 15:23:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Ben, please +W'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-05-10 18:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-03 07:42:01.000000000', 'message': "[ThreadGroup] Don't remove timer when stop timers

Remove inner timers only when loop calls' grateful
exits completed.

Change-Id: I2e52b680a09d337d9b598a4826132df8c7b0b4d9
"}, {'created': '2018-04-03 12:00:56.000000000', 'message': "[ThreadGroup] Don't remove timer when stop timers

Graceful exit is not working since we removed the timers
before waiting them to complete.

Change-Id: I2e52b680a09d337d9b598a4826132df8c7b0b4d9
"}, {'created': '2018-05-08 06:52:36.000000000', 'message': "[ThreadGroup] Don't remove timer when stop timers

Graceful exit is not working since we removed the timers
before waiting them to complete.

Closes-Bug: #1769825
Change-Id: I2e52b680a09d337d9b598a4826132df8c7b0b4d9
"}, {'created': '2018-05-09 00:55:11.000000000', 'message': "[ThreadGroup] Don't remove timer when stop timers

Graceful exit is not working since we removed the timers
before waiting them to complete.

Closes-Bug: #1769825
Change-Id: I2e52b680a09d337d9b598a4826132df8c7b0b4d9
"}]
commit_message:
[ThreadGroup] Don't remove timer when stop timers

Graceful exit is not working since we removed the timers
before waiting them to complete.

Closes-Bug: #1769825
Change-Id: I2e52b680a09d337d9b598a4826132df8c7b0b4d9

but should be pointing to stable/pike.

So I created a separate repo for os-vif-bigswitch [1]. Got sidetracked and forgot to move the code there. Its currently just cookiecutter.
Let me move the code there and then change the pointer in the release note here to point to that repo.

This might be a dumb question, but is there any way we can propose a couple of DNM Depends-On patches, one for devstack that will install the os-vif-bigswitch package and then one for neutron that will run a tempest job that uses the Big Switch backend? So we can see if removing this code and running instead with the os-vif-bigswitch plugin hasn't broken anything?"}, {'account_id': 20751, 'date': '2018-05-01 21:26:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> This might be a dumb question, but is there any way we can propose
 > a couple of DNM Depends-On patches, one for devstack that will
 > install the os-vif-bigswitch package and then one for neutron that
 > will run a tempest job that uses the Big Switch backend? So we can
 > see if removing this code and running instead with the
 > os-vif-bigswitch plugin hasn't broken anything?

Thats a good idea - I'm not sure if that'd be feasible though.
When you say deploy Big Switch backend, it would include a Big Switch
controller as well - since the virtual switch would look for a controller
to connect to when it boots up.
Once upon a time, there used to be a bsn-openstack-ci - but there
were some internal changes in the setup and it has since been down.
Currently I have an internal tempest setup which is run by jenkins
every night that does that testing."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-01 21:51:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> > This might be a dumb question, but is there any way we can

 > that

 > Switch

 > controller
 > to connect to when it boots up.
 > Once upon a time, there used to be a bsn-openstack-ci - but there
 > were some internal changes in the setup and it has since been down.
 > Currently I have an internal tempest setup which is run by jenkins
 > every night that does that testing.

I see -- thank you for explaining all of that."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-05-02 08:07:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1

Let me know and I'll push a patch if needed :)"}, {'account_id': 20751, 'date': '2018-05-07 14:40:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Stephen, just to follow up on this and close any queries that you might have - os-vif's VIFBase class has PortProfile, where nullable!=true.
So ideally, it should have some value, VifPortProfileBase being the minimal object[1]

Sahid has also confirmed it being the os-vif core.

Taking that into consideration, does this change need any further updates?

commit_message:
remove IVS plug/unplug as they're moved to separate plugin

 - as per the bug #1704129, the plug/unplug is moved to a
   separate os-vif plugin
 - IVS's methods have also been moved to a separate package
   called os-vif-bigswitch [1]
 - hence removing all dangling calls from here

[1] https://github.com/bigswitch/os-vif-bigswitch

Partial-Bug: #1704129

commit_message:
Add support for using distribution packages for OpenStack services

Distributions provide packages for the OpenStack services so we add
support for using these instead of the pip ones.

Change-Id: I026a440b6a0fda43b613e30f359b2a23c3c1151f
Depends-On: I5a78e2120e596d36629b4ba978b2b5df76b149b0
Implements: blueprint openstack-distribution-packages

commit_message:
OSH-infra multinode gate rework

This moves to using bash scripts for deploying the charts for the
multinode gates in osh-infra as opposed to using the ansible
chart builder

Change-Id: I2951ccf57250a5e6e272872f2d6f7a81bd11f184

[{'created': '2018-05-10 19:23:04.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Disable limestone"

The hypervisor the mirror is located on had a bad memory module. The module is replaced and the mirror is back online now.

This reverts commit 894156d29527c4bfc3c6667bdd36a998e52e5cc8.

Change-Id: Ic7d9967c4603752dcb3aee9e7435d0f2d1c38487
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Disable limestone"

The hypervisor the mirror is located on had a bad memory module. The module is replaced and the mirror is back online now.

This reverts commit 894156d29527c4bfc3c6667bdd36a998e52e5cc8.

Change-Id: Ic7d9967c4603752dcb3aee9e7435d0f2d1c38487

commit_message:
Provide an example for switch port configurations

This change provides an example switch configuration and topology
that illustrates what is required in a real deployment of OpenStack.

Change-Id: Ie72eef3848671e42034cc7038cff0fbd03d60622
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add information about restoring inventory from backup

OSA has long had an inventory archive which can be used to restore
inventory in the even that something goes wrong. This change adds to the
troubleshooting guide to illustrate how to restore inventory from
backup.

Change-Id: Iacba866f1e5b534ecdb620e4890a0c710c8adf5c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Fix _setUpExtension shim

[1] recently converted _setUpExtension in [2] into a shim for a new
setup_extension method where an unused argument (resource_attribute_map)
is removed. In the process, a bug was introduced when calling the
new method by calling it with predefined values. This patch fixes it.

[1] Ia59fc1978228f9982d3ee447ebcfcb712eebbdb7
[2] neutron.tests.unit.extensions.base

Closes-Bug: #1769704

Change-Id: I39fb64d76809f49526e557e39cb07dfd9abdf9cb

commit_message:
Setup /dev/random and /dev/urandom device in cache prep

In the cache preparation stage, there are certain libraries that
depend on the existance of /dev/random and /dev/urandom in order
to be able to function correctly, such as NSS in the latest CentOS
release (7.5)

This patch adds those nodes so that the libraries are able to use
them with no problems, allowing yum and rpm specifically to work
properly again.

Change-Id: Iaf6b9cb1435591f28289493f480a7fe46789c551
(cherry picked from commit 62a38e086ad85325574873719c63aca9b2b4dfaa)

Setup /dev/random and /dev/urandom device in cache prep

In the cache preparation stage, there are certain libraries that
depend on the existance of /dev/random and /dev/urandom in order
to be able to function correctly, such as NSS in the latest CentOS

This patch adds those nodes so that the libraries are able to use
them with no problems, allowing yum and rpm specifically to work
properly again.

commit_message:
Bump default timeout values

We're getting a fair number of timeouts sporadically. The VMs seem to
just be running a bit slower... give ourselves a bit more headroom.

Change-Id: I74ffd304d581e7449b8f850b2412ef1dce6effb1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-10 16:56:30.000000000', 'message': "Remove docs/requirements.txt from py_pkgs lookup output

There is no need to build the docs python packages when doing
a repo build. The packages aren't required for a successful
deployment of OpenStack. The output of their data just adds
noise to the output of the lookup, and delays the build with
unnecessary extra wheel builds.

Change-Id: Ia60e1a49d9befdbafdaf89e5cf21e17985a706e7
"}]
commit_message:
Remove docs/requirements.txt from py_pkgs lookup output

There is no need to build the docs python packages when doing
a repo build. The packages aren't required for a successful
deployment of OpenStack. The output of their data just adds
noise to the output of the lookup, and delays the build with
unnecessary extra wheel builds.

Change-Id: Ia60e1a49d9befdbafdaf89e5cf21e17985a706e7

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I44a46d05b5818c30657f123ae714b4189c506aae
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
